title: Boot from cd to pull in network ISO

forumNotes.author: Lateralus
forumNotes.content:
Ok I am kinda new at this but please bare with me.   

Here's what I would like to do. I have all these OS (bootable isos) and Diag tools(also bootable iso's) on a network drive. I would like to create 1 boot cd to insert into a PC that would look to that network drives folder then let me type in a command to load which ever ISO I want. That way I wouldn't have to hunt for all these different cds when ever I want to install a particular version of windows.   

I am not really picky on the method just the general idea. 1 boot cd to run any bootable ISO on a network drive  

I don't know if that's possible or not but it seems like it should be, a kick in the right direction would be much appreciated

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> I am not really picky on the method just the general idea. 1 boot cd to run ***any*** bootable ***ISO*** on a network drive  
>
> I don't know if that's possible or not but it seems like it should be, a kick in the right direction would be much appreciated
Forget (for the moment ![:thumbup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbup.gif)) about the network thingy.  

Start reading here ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif):  
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=8944](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=8944 "External link")  

You will need to test the bootability of each single .iso locally.  
Only ONCE this part is cleared we will start messing with the network.  

![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  

Wonko

Thank you that post was helpful. I went through and read some forums and I get that each ISO is a bit different and may require a different boot loader, so let me simplify this then. I dont need this to be an end all be all just something to simplify my life; a net effect is what I am going for. Something that covers a high percentage but probably not everything or maybe not even a majority.   

So for my purposes Lets just say its the X.iso is one of the following :  

Windows XP , Windows Vista and Windows 7. (all the various versions of those OS's 64bit, ultimate... whatever)

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
Good. ![:thumbup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbup.gif)  

Now you have to try the known methods for them.  

You can find some info here:  
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=5041](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=5041 "External link")  

And some here:  
[http://www.msfn.org/...aded-iso-image/](http://www.msfn.org/board/topic/137714-install-xp-from-a-ram-loaded-iso-image/ "External link")  

For the record, the sense of the previously given thread was not about the need of a different bootloader, "THE" bootloader is grub4dos (an alternative is Syslinux/memdisk), point is if there is a known working method to boot with it any given .iso.  

Once found it, it is needed to verify that it can be "transposed" over network use.  

**BUT** , ultimately, your ***GOAL*** is to be able to install XP, Vista ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) and Windows 7 from the network.  
The need for loading and installing from a .iso is the ***MEANS*** that you thought to use.  

In other words, your question should now become "How can I install the said Operating System from network after having booted the local PC from a CD?"  

The actual answer to this ***new*** question may involve NOT the use of the install source in the form of a .iso image.  

![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  
Wonko
